results.title: Jude
results.creator_credit: Michael Winterbottom, Andrew Eaton and Revolution Films
results.brief_description: Jude Fawley is a stonemason who loves learning. Inspired by his childhood schoolmaster, he longs to attend university and singlemindedly studies in the hope of gaining a place. His studies are interrupted when Jude blindly falls for and marries Arabella Dunn, the daughter of a local pig farmer. After a brief and unhappy marriage he moves to Christminster to be closer to his beloved scholars. There he meets and falls fatally in love with his cousin Sue Bridehead. The ill-fated lovers join in an illicit union that flouts society’s conventions and tragedy ensues. Based on the novel “Jude the obscure” by Thomas Hardy.

results.title: A Night in Casablanca
results.creator_credit: Archie Mayo, David Leow and Louis Vista Productions
results.brief_description: The setting for this inspired piece of Marx mayhem is the fabulous Hotel Casablanca in North Africa, where the hotel managers are dropping like flies. Each one is being murdered as he innocently blunders onto the stolen jewels and art treasures hidden in the hotel by a gang of escaped Nazis. Enter Groucho as the new manager, with Chico as his self-appointed bodyguard, aided and abetted by Harpo, the mischevious valetto villainous gang leader, Sig Rumann, and pandemonium quickly ensues. In their last important film together, the Marx Brothers are pulled into one crazy situation after another. The many plot twists put the boys through their hilarious paces, building the action to a sustained frenzy, and culminating in an outrageous chase scene complete with airplane acrobatics.

results.title: Les Dames du Bois de Boulogne
results.creator_credit: Robert Bresson, Raoul Ploquin and Films Raoul Ploquin
results.brief_description: Made during the last days of the Occupation, the film combines the superficial glamour of Parisian high society with the seething passions and jealousies that cause a spurned femme fatale, Helene (Maria Casares) to seek her ex-lover’s humiliation (Paul Bernard). Helene seeks out two former friends, madame D (Lucienne Bogaert) and her daughter Agnes (Elina Labourdette), a talented dancer who has been forced into prostitution to support herself and her mother. After rescuing them from their desparate situation, Helene ensures that Jean meets Agnes, in the knowledge that he will fall in love and pursue her affections, urged on by Helene’s description of Agnes’s unattainability and chasteness. The inexorable logic of Helene’s scheme seems complete when Jean and Agnes are married, but through the revelation of truth Bresson delivers one of the most moving affirmations of the transcendent and redemptive powers of love. With dialogue written by writer/filmmaker Jean Cocteau, “Les Dames du Bois du Boulogne” was adapted to the screen by Bresson from an anecdote in Denis Diderot’s “Jacques Le Fataliste”. In French with English sub-titles.

results.title: Fontane Effi Briest = Effi Briest
results.creator_credit: Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Filverlag der Authoren and Tango Film
results.brief_description: Possibly Fassbinder’s most exquisite film, this is the story of a seventeen year old girl stifled in a loveless marriage, too naive to understand that her liaison with one of her husband’s friends risks bringing disaster on both of them. Using carefully stylised visuals and performances, Fassbinder produces not a conventional literary adaptation but a searching study of the ways that people can unwittingly conspire in their own downfall. From the novel by Theodor Fontane. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Fox and his friends = Faustrecht der freiheit
results.creator_credit: Rainer Werner Fassbinder, City-Film, GmbH and Tango-Film
results.brief_description: The only one of Fassbinder’s films to explicitly centre on gay male relationships, this film tells the story of a young, working class, unemployed lottery winner who is exploited, with tragic consequences, by his new-found ‘middle class’ friends. This is one of the director’s best socially critical melodramas, focussing on a victim who conspires in his own victimisation, and using the framework of a love story to lay bare the mechanisms of class exploitation. The film’s avoidance of specifically gay issues, and its bleak representation of gay lifestyles, outraged many in the gay community at the time of its release. Now, however, Fassbinder’s presumption that gay men are fundamentally the same as everyone else looks startlingly modern. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: The Bitter tears of Petra von Kant = Die Bitteren tranen der Petra von Kant
results.brief_description: Fassbinder originally wrote this as a play for the stage and he filmed it less than one year after its theatrical debut. The film remains entirely set in Petra von Kant’s room and remains divided into five ‘acts’, in each of which Petra wears a different wig. Accompanied by the music of Verdi, The Platters and The Walker Brothers, dressed in an incredible melange of glitter and Cecil B. de Mille, imprisoned in a florid set dominated by fleshy nudes and ghastly white mannequins, three women act out a super-charged melodrama of sado-masochistic passion.

results.title: The American soldier = Der Americkanische soldat
results.brief_description: In what Fassbinder describes as a ‘study of a perfect killer’ his American soldier is actually a German, recently returned from Vietnam with some newly developed skills to exploit. Stepping into the Munich underworld as a hired killer, Ricky (in his white suit and soft hat, one of the many movie references scattered throughout this noir-influenced thriller) finds he has entered a world of bluff and double-bluff, from the opening card game to the closing pay-off. Although the characters may be familiar from earlier Fassbinder films - the ageing rent-boy, the fickle moll, and unsmiling, sadistic policemen - the director has added a significance and weight to their cliched behaviour and stereotypical actions that invest the film with a knowing cynicism and a very dark humour. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Rashomon = In the woods
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Jinkichi Minoura and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: A woodcutter (Takashi Shimura) witnesses a horrific series of events: A noble man (Mayasuki Mori) and his wife (Machiko Kyo) are ambushed by the famous bandit Tajomaru (Toshiro Mifune). The wife is raped and the nobleman is killed in a duel. Tajomaru is arrested and tried. In the telling of the tale in front of the judge, however, each of the four participants - the bandit, the wife, the woodcutter, the ghost of the murdered nobleman - gives a different view of what actually happened. Is any of them telling the truth? Akira Kurosawa leaves us to ponder the subjective nature of Truth. In this work he borrows heavily from Japan’s artistic tradition, specially kabuki theatre, where events are often repeated with slight variations. Winner of Golden Lion, Venice, 1951. Adapted from two original stories by Ryunosuke Akugatawa (“Rashomon” and “In a grove”).

results.title: At war with the army
results.creator_credit: Hal Walker, Fred F Finklehoffe and Screen Associates International
results.brief_description: One of Hollywood’s greatest comedy duos, Jerry Lewis and Dean Martin star in this screwball comedy about romance, friendship and the military. Martin plays a dejected Romeo, experiencing girlfriend problems and his pal Lewis tries valiantly, but often with comic results, to help out in the love department. Based on the play of the same name by James B Allardice. Also starring Polly Bergen and Mike Kellin.

results.title: Little boy lost
results.creator_credit: Terry Bourke, Alan Spires and Summit International
results.brief_description: Based on an event that occurred in the township of Guyra, NSW, in 1960, this video is dedicated to the volunteers involved in the search for four year old Stephen Walls. Stephen disappeared whilst watching his father sheep herding. Initially it’s the police and local farmers who begin the search, but as night falls and it becomes evident Stephen may not be found, hundreds of locals join in. By the third day volunteers have spilled beyond the confines of the local community as interstate army brigades and other services are supplied. Stephen is eventually found after four days and three nights, in good health. This film highlight the dedication of the volunteers and the faith of Jacko and Dorrie Walls that their son would return to them safely. Starring John Hargreaves, Lorna Lesley, Tony Elliot and Nathan Dawes as Stephen Walls. Adapted from a storyline by John Powell and Suzanne Turner.
